message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Manufacturing Consent
Paper Abstract: Chapter 6 empirically tests whether and how participatory technologies influence political attitudes. Using two original survey experiments and qualitative data from interviews and focus groups, this chapter examines the impact of awareness of the Direct Line on approval of President Putin and perceptions of voice. The results indicate that participatory technologies have a positive impact on attitudes toward authorities. It also argues that, while government responsiveness to citizen demands does improve attitudes toward autocrats, the mere presence of participation opportunities bolsters support regardless of authorities' response to these demands.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

Links: [{"title":"Vladimir Putin - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vladimir_Putin"},{"title":"Russia under Vladimir Putin - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Russia_under_Vladimir_Putin"},{"title":"Family of Vladimir Putin - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Family_of_Vladimir_Putin"},{"title":"Claims of Vladimir Putin's incapacity and death - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Claims_of_Vladimir_Putin's_incapacity_and_death"},{"title":"Crimean speech of Vladimir Putin - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Crimean_speech_of_Vladimir_Putin"},{"title":"Vladimir Putin's rise to power - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vladimir_Putin's_rise_to_power"},{"title":"Domestic policy of Vladimir Putin - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Domestic_policy_of_Vladimir_Putin"},{"title":"2007 Munich speech of Vladimir Putin - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2007_Munich_speech_of_Vladimir_Putin"},{"title":"Vladimir Putin's language - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vladimir_Putin's_language"},{"title":"Pets of Vladimir Putin - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pets_of_Vladimir_Putin"}]

I've completed the web search for "Vladimir Putin." Here's a summary of the key information found:

## Basic Information

Vladimir Vladimirovich Putin (born 7 October 1952) is a Russian politician and former intelligence officer who has served as President of Russia since 2012, having previously served from 2000 to 2008.(no content)Putin also served as Prime Minister of Russia from 1999 to 2000 and again from 2008 to 2012.

## Background and Family

Putin was born on 7 October 1952 in Leningrad, Soviet Union (now Saint Petersburg, Russia), the youngest of three children.(no content)His grandfather, Spiridon Putin, was a personal cook to Vladimir Lenin and Joseph Stalin.

## Rise to Power

On 31 December 1999, following the resignation of President Boris Yeltsin, he was appointed Acting President. He was first elected President of Russia on 26 March 2000, and then re-elected in 2004, 2012, 2018, and 2024.

## Policies

Throughout his subsequent terms, alternately serving as president and Prime Minister, Putin has overseen extensive reforms aimed at consolidating state power, restructuring federal relations, and curbing the influence of oligarchs.

The search results contain extensive information about Putin's political career, domestic policies, foreign policy positions, and various other aspects of his life and leadership.

message_text:
Web search results for query: "Participatory democracy"

Links: [{"title":"Participatory democracy - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Participatory_democracy"},{"title":"Participatory democracy in the European Union - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Participatory_democracy_in_the_European_Union"},{"title":"Category:Participatory democracy - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Participatory_democracy"},{"title":"Strong Democracy - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Strong_Democracy"},{"title":"Participatory justice - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Participatory_justice"},{"title":"Types of democracy - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Types_of_democracy"},{"title":"Grassroots democracy - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Grassroots_democracy"},{"title":"Decidim - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Decidim"},{"title":"Green Left Party - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Party_of_the_Greens_and_the_Left_Future"},{"title":"Participative decision-making in organizations - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Participative_decision-making"}]

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about participatory democracy:

## Definition

Participatory democracy is a form of government in which citizens participate individually and directly in political decisions and policies that affect their lives, rather than through elected representatives.(no content)It is primarily concerned with ensuring that citizens have the opportunity to be involved in decision-making on matters that affect their lives.

## Historical Background

Participatory democracy is not a new concept and has existed in various forms since Athenian democracy.(no content)Its modern theory was developed by Jean-Jacques Rousseau in the 18th century and later promoted by John Stuart Mill and G. D. H. Cole, who argued that political participation is indispensable for a just society.

## Modern Implementation

In the early 21st century, participatory democracy has been more widely studied and experimented with, leading to various institutional reform ideas such as participatory budgeting. Notable examples include:

- Porto Alegre, Brazil adapted a system of participatory budgeting in 1989.
- In a US example, the plans to rebuild New Orleans after Hurricane Katrina in 2005 were drafted and approved by thousands of ordinary citizens.
- Participatory democracy was a notable feature of the Occupy movement in 2011, where "Occupy camps" around the world made decisions based on the outcome of working groups where every protester had a say.

## Distinction from Representative Democracy

Participatory democracy refers to mechanisms through which citizens are involved in public decision-making processes, not as an alternative to representative democracy but as a complement to it.

message_text:
Web search results for query: "Survey methodology"

Links: [{"title":"Survey methodology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Survey_methodology"},{"title":"Journal of Survey Statistics and Methodology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Journal_of_Survey_Statistics_and_Methodology"},{"title":"Category:Survey methodology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Survey_methodology"},{"title":"Joint Program in Survey Methodology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Joint_Program_in_Survey_Methodology"},{"title":"Net promoter score - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Net_promoter_score"},{"title":"Health Survey for England - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Health_Survey_for_England"},{"title":"Survey on Household Income and Wealth - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Survey_on_Household_Income_and_Wealth"},{"title":"National Student Survey - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Student_Survey"},{"title":"Qualitative research - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Qualitative_research"},{"title":"Dark Energy Survey - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Dark_Energy_Survey"}]

## Survey Methodology

Based on the search results, here's an overview of survey methodology:

### Definition and Scope

Survey methodology is both a scientific field and a profession, meaning that some professionals in the field focus on survey errors empirically and others design surveys to reduce them.(no content)As a scientific field, it seeks to identify principles about sample design, data collection instruments, statistical adjustment of data, and data processing that can create systematic and random survey errors.

### Key Components

A single survey is made of at least a sample (or full population in the case of a census), a method of data collection (e.g., a questionnaire) and individual questions or items that become data that can be analyzed statistically.(no content)Surveys provide important information for all kinds of public-information and research fields, such as marketing research, psychology, health-care provision and sociology.

### Survey Design Considerations

For survey designers, the task involves making a large set of decisions about thousands of individual features of a survey in order to improve it, with key methodological challenges including decisions on how to identify and select potential sample members.

### Emerging Developments

Since 2018, survey methodologists have started to examine how big data can complement survey methodology to allow researchers and practitioners to improve the production of survey statistics and its quality.

For survey designers, the task involves making a large set of decisions about thousands of individual features of a survey in order to improve it, with key methodological challenges including decisions on how to identify and select potential sample members.

### Emerging Developments

Since 2018, survey methodologists have started to examine how big data can complement survey methodology to allow researchers and practitioners to improve the production of survey statistics and its quality.

Based on the search results, here's an overview of qualitative research:

## Definition and Purpose

Qualitative research is often used to explore complex phenomena or to gain insight into people's experiences and perspectives on a particular topic.

## Fields of Application

Qualitative research methods have been used in sociology, anthropology, political science, psychology, communication studies, social work, folklore, educational research, information science and software engineering research.

## Philosophical Foundations

Qualitative research examines aspects of human life, including culture, expression, beliefs, morality, life stress, and imagination.(no content)Several philosophical and psychological traditions have influenced investigators' approaches to qualitative research, including phenomenology, social constructionism, symbolic interactionism, and positivism.

## Data Collection Methods

Qualitative researchers may gather information through observations, note-taking, interviews, focus groups (group interviews), documents, images and artifacts.(no content)Data sources include interview transcripts, videos of social interactions, notes, verbal reports and artifacts such as books or works of art.

## Common Methodologies

Several qualitative research approaches include:
- Grounded theory, which is an inductive type of research, based on a very close look at the empirical observations a study yields.
- Thematic analysis, which involves analyzing patterns of meaning.
- Narrative inquiry, which studies the narratives that people use to describe their experience.

Web search results for query: "Political attitude"

Links: [{"title":"Political spectrum - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Political_spectrum"},{"title":"Punk ideologies - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Punk_ideologies"},{"title":"Political views of Adolf Hitler - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Political_views_of_Adolf_Hitler"},{"title":"Laissez-faire - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Laissez-faire"},{"title":"Political culture - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Political_culture"},{"title":"Political socialization - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Political_socialization"},{"title":"Attitude: The New Subversive Cartoonists - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Attitude:_The_New_Subversive_Cartoonists"},{"title":"Reactionary - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reactionary"},{"title":"Political theology in China - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Political_theology_in_China"},{"title":"Parochialism - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Parochialism"}]

Based on the web search results, here's an overview of political attitude:

## Definition and Significance

Political attitude is defined as "the set of attitudes, beliefs, and sentiments, which give order and meaning to a political process and which provide the underlying assumptions and rules that govern behavior in the political system".

## How Political Attitudes Form

Political socialization is the process by which individuals internalize and develop their political values, ideas, attitudes, and perceptions via the agents of socialization.(no content)The most significant agents include, but are not limited to, families, media, education, and peers.(no content)The family is the most influential agent, with literature suggesting that family and the transmission of attitudes from parent to child are the most prominent agents of socialization, with especially strong support for the transmission of voting behaviour, partisanship and religious attitudes.

## Research on Political Attitudes

Scholars have identified various dimensions of political attitudes. In 1950, Leonard W. Ferguson analyzed political values using ten scales measuring attitudes toward various issues and identified three factors: religionism, humanitarianism and nationalism. Later researchers like Hans Eysenck and Ronald Inglehart developed different frameworks for understanding how political attitudes structure themselves across populations.

Trust is a major factor in political culture, as its level determines the capacity of the state to function.

Web search results for query: "Focus group"

Links: [{"title":"Focus group - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Focus_group"},{"title":"The Focus Group - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Focus_Group"},{"title":"Online focus group - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Online_focus_group"},{"title":"Focus (band) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Focus_(band)"},{"title":"List of Focus members - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_Focus_members"},{"title":"The Focus Group (business) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Focus_Group_(business)"},{"title":"ITU-WHO Focus Group on Artificial Intelligence for Health - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ITU-WHO_Focus_Group_on_Artificial_Intelligence_for_Health"},{"title":"Focus Group (disambiguation) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Focus_Group_(disambiguation)"},{"title":"Focus Financial Partners - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Focus_Financial_Partners"},{"title":"Focus Humanitarian Assistance - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Focus_Humanitarian_Assistance"}]

Based on the search results, here's information about focus groups:

## Definition and Purpose

A focus group is a group interview involving a small number (sometimes up to twelve) of demographically predefined participants, whose reactions to specific researcher/evaluator-posed questions are studied.(no content)Focus groups are used in market research to better understand people's reactions to products or services or participants' perceptions of shared experiences.

## Applications

In market research, focus groups can explore a group's response to a new product or service, and as a program evaluation tool, they can elicit lessons learned and recommendations for performance improvement.(no content)Focus groups are also used by sociologists, psychologists, and researchers in communication studies, education, political science, and public health.

## How They Work

Instead of a researcher/evaluator asking group members questions individually, focus groups use group interaction to explore and clarify participants' beliefs, opinions, and views.(no content)While the focus group is taking place, the facilitator either takes notes and/or records the discussion for later note-taking in order to learn from the group.

## Advantages

An advantage of focus groups is their fairly low cost compared to surveys because focus groups allow a researcher to obtain results relatively quickly and increase the sample size by including several people at once.

## History

Focus groups first started in the 1940s as a research method in the context of market research concerning radio soap operas, and the term "focus group" was coined by psychologist and marketing expert Ernest Dichter.

Links: [{"title":"E-government - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/E-government"},{"title":"e-participation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/E-participation"},{"title":"E-governance - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/E-governance"},{"title":"E-governance in the United States - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/E-governance_in_the_United_States"},{"title":"E-democracy - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/E-democracy"},{"title":"E-Government Act of 2002 - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/E-Government_Act_of_2002"},{"title":"Comparison of civic technology platforms - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Comparison_of_civic_technology_platforms"},{"title":"Civic engagement - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Civic_engagement"},{"title":"Public participation (decision making) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Public_participation_(decision_making)"},{"title":"Public participation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Public_participation"}]

I've completed the web search for "E-government citizen participation." Here are the key findings:

## Definition and Overview

Electronic participation (e-participation) refers to the use of ICT in facilitating citizen participation in government-related processes, encompassing areas such as administration, service delivery, decision-making, and policy-making.

## Key Interactive Features

Through the Internet's Web 2.0 interactive features, people from all over the country can provide input to politicians or public servants and make their voices heard. Blogging and interactive surveys allow politicians or public servants to see the views of the people on any issue.

## Different Interaction Models

E-government involves digital interactions across various levels and stakeholders (C2G), between governments and other government agencies (G2G), between government and citizens (G2C), between government and employees (G2E), and between government and businesses/commerces (G2B).

## Government 2.0 Approach

Gov 2.0 combines interactive Web 2.0 fundamentals with e-government and increases citizen participation by using open-source platforms, which allow development of innovative apps, websites, and widgets.

## Measuring E-Participation

The E-Participation Index (EPI) is a tool developed by the UN Department of Economic and Social Affairs. It serves as a supplementary index to the UN E-Government Survey and is used to assess the effectiveness of online services that facilitate information exchange and interaction between government and citizens, and citizen involvement in policy and decision-making. The EPI evaluates the extent to which a government provides information to its constituents, involves citizens in policy design, and empowers citizens in decision-making processes, forming the framework of "e-information", "e-consultation", and "e-decision making".

Web search results for query: "Political legitimacy"

Links: [{"title":"Political legitimacy - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Political_legitimacy"},{"title":"Legitimation crisis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Legitimation_crisis"},{"title":"The Legitimation of Power - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Legitimation_of_Power"},{"title":"Political authority - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Political_authority"},{"title":"Consequentialist justifications of the state - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Consequentialist_justifications_of_the_state"},{"title":"Consent of the governed - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Consent_of_the_governed"},{"title":"Legitimacy of the State of Israel - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Calls_for_the_destruction_of_Israel"},{"title":"Authority - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authority"},{"title":"International reactions to the 2020 Belarusian presidential election and 2020–2021 protests - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/International_reactions_to_the_2020_Belarusian_presidential_election_and_2020%E2%80%932021_protests"},{"title":"Power (social and political) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Power_(social_and_political)"}]

Based on the web search results, here's information about political legitimacy:

## Definition

In political science, legitimacy has traditionally been understood as the popular acceptance and recognition by the public of the authority of a political actor, whereby authority of such a regime has political power through consent and mutual understandings, not coercion.

## Key Philosophical Perspectives

The Enlightenment-era British social philosopher John Locke said that political legitimacy derives from popular explicit and implicit consent of the governed.(no content)The American political sociologist Seymour Martin Lipset said that legitimacy also "involves the capacity of a political system to engender and maintain the belief that existing political institutions are the most appropriate and proper ones for the society".

## Types of Political Legitimacy

The three types of political legitimacy described by German sociologist Max Weber are traditional, charismatic, and rational-legal: Traditional legitimacy derives from societal custom and habit that emphasize the history of the authority of tradition.(no content)Charismatic legitimacy derives from the ideas and personal charisma of the leader, a person whose authoritative persona charms and psychologically dominates the people of the society to agreement with the government's régime and rule.(no content)Rational-legal legitimacy derives from a system of institutional procedure, wherein government institutions establish and enforce law and order in the public interest.

## Consent of the Governed

In political philosophy, consent of the governed is the idea that a government's legitimacy and moral right to use state power is justified and lawful only when consented to by the people or society over which that political power is exercised.

message_text:
Excellent! I've successfully completed the analysis of the "Manufacturing Consent" paper. Here's a summary of what was accomplished:

## Analysis Complete ✅

**Paper Classification:** Contribution
- The paper presents original survey experiments and qualitative research, making novel empirical contributions to understanding how participatory technologies influence political attitudes.

**Triples Identified and Validated:** 8 entities

1. **Participatory democracy** (concept, uses) - The foundational framework for understanding citizen participation
2. **Survey methodology** (method, uses) - Primary quantitative research approach
3. **Focus group** (method, uses) - Qualitative data collection technique
4. **Qualitative research** (method, uses) - Broader qualitative research tradition
5. **Political socialization** (concept, uses) - How citizens develop political views and attitudes
6. **E-participation** (concept, uses) - Digital platforms for citizen engagement (the Direct Line)
7. **Political legitimacy** (concept, proposes) - Key contribution: demonstrating that participation opportunities themselves increase support for authorities
8. **Vladimir Putin** (other, uses) - Subject of the empirical analysis

**Validation Result:** ✅ PASSED
- All Wikipedia URLs verified
- Proper entity types assigned
- At least 1 "uses" relation present (requirement met)
- At least 1 "proposes" relation present for contribution paper (requirement met)

The analysis reveals that this paper makes important theoretical contributions about how mere participation opportunities (regardless of government responsiveness) can enhance political legitimacy and support for authorities.
